Momodora III is an okay game, but now its story time.

First off you can play as two characters Momo Reinol or Kaho Reinol but really it adds nothing to story and the only difference is playing as Momo is hard mode and Kaho is easy mode. Anyway evil apparitions appear around the village of KoHo it’s up to Momo Reinol or Kaho Reinol to stop it.

Now this game is bare bones, its way more simple and easy unlike Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight. But this game came out way before MRUTM come about so I won’t hold it against them, for the most part. 

As I have said this game is really bare bones there are some variety of items and secrets but and a hidden boss, but really that’s about it, you can beat this game in an hour or more if you’re getting achievements.

But I wish they put more in this game like putting the first two games in this and maybe an art book or something but I don’t know.

Now with all that said, I say get this game if you want an okay time waster, but really that’s about it.

レートを付けるなら 6/10 くらい。

↓書いた直後にオプションを知ったので撤回します。
[strike]理由はダメージを与えたときに画面が揺れる効果があるのだが、それが大きすぎて自機を見失いやすいから。
攻撃後の硬直やヒットストップがないので相手のスキを見て近づいたら攻撃ボタン連打することになる。そうするとエフェクトと画面揺れで敵キャラの動きが見えなくなるのが自分には大きなマイナスだった。[/strike]
ゲーム開始前（セーブスロットを選択したあと）にオプション設定をすることができる。Screenshake はキャラを見失うくらいに画面ゆれがひどいので Off にしておこう。素の解像度は240pで Video Setteings は拡大率の選択なのだが、おそらく解像度のせいで Steam Overlay と相性が悪いのだと思うが、ウィンドウの外側の見えないところにオーバーレイが描画されてしまう。スクリーンショットは ゲーム画面の外側まで写ってしまうし、Big Picture は見切れるし、実績解除の通知などは見えない。

Momodora:RUtM のあとでこちらをプレイすると、足場を渡るプラットフォーマー要素が目立つので期待したのと違う… と思うかもしれない。
とはいえ、隠しアイテムを見つけたり実績解除のやり応えは短い作品ながらもそれなりにあるし、シリーズの他作品にも登場するキャラクターも登場するし、Momodora が好きなら楽しめると思う。

36185840.review:
¿Que es Momodora III?
Un juego de plataformas tipo metroidvania en 2D sucesora de 2 juegos con su mismo nombre, nos cuentan la historia de Momo y Dora (Isadora) 2 sacerdotisas que deben investigar la extraña aparición de monstruos en su pueblo, viajando por distintos lugares

Lo bueno y lo malo:
+ADORO TODO LO VISUAL DE ESTE JUEGO
+Personajes y enemigos carismaticos (Y adorables a más no poder <3)
+Jugabilidad sencilla y cómoda
+El modo casual para que todo el mundo pueda disfrutarlo
-Juego muy MUY corto. En menos de una hora/3 cuartos de hora te pasas todo el juego (Eso si te pones a investigar y te tomas tu tiempo)
-Apenas hay difilcultad. Me explico el hard no es hard, te quita un poco de la vida y poco más

8,5/10 - Muy bueno y muy recomendable

35925466.review: this is a pretty good game. my main motivation for writing this review is actually to recommend NOT playing it before Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight. i feel like the lower price tag may be incentive to do that. even if you go in expecting it to be lesser than a sequel just to get a taste, it still doesn't hint at the huge gap in quality between the two games. that being said, this game's short length and overall quality still makes it a fun game to check out after being spoiled by Momodora 4. it's a blast of charming platformer fun with that same unique Momodora world that doesn't overstay its welcome. this is for the best, because the mechanical design is already somewhat limited. things like the bosses stick out like a sore thumb, with barely any attack patterns and feeling like an obligation rather than an inspired part of the experience. anyway, it's a very likable game. just try and play Momodora 4 first, in case you find this one a little too insubstantial.

Gameplay : 3/5
Sound and Music : 3/5
Visuals : 5/5
Replayability : 4/5
Story : 1/5

Overall : 3.2

I wouldn’t call this a metroidvania, it more follows along the line of the first game except with different environments and more boss fights. The gameplay was fine but more of the same and I found a way to break it without really trying. So I just played on hard cause there wasn’t a normal mode. I got the items that increases damage when you have low health, make your charge attack longer, and add poison to your charge attack to kill every boss within seconds pretty much. Sound and Music is nothing special. The visuals are really good though, everything is really pretty to look at. It’s a quick game but there’s tons of secrets I guess, I didn’t find any I don’t think but I would want to go back and play it again to find them while trying a new playstyle, so replayability is good. The story is the same as the last two and is dull by now, except it has some odd ending that didn’t make sense but I think there’s multiple endings so whatever. It was fun and good and worth your time, only about an hour.

35232983.review:
[h1] Momodora III [/h1]
Vaya juego, es muy difícil no recomendar tal joya, muchas personas lo comparan con el Dark Souls, pero en realidad son 2 joyas muy buenas y no tiene que enviarle nada la una a la otra... la sinopsis personal de este juego: [i] Nos vemos centrados en la historia de dos chicas: Momo y Dora, las cuales son sacerdotisas, y como toda sacerdotisa su misión es llevar a cabo la purificación, a medida que avanzamos conoceremos NPCs bastante divertidos y carismáticos [b][spoiler](kawaii intesifies)[/spoiler][/b], encontrando ítems que serán de mucha ayuda en el camino, escenarios totalmente ambientados que aumentan la experiencia del jugador, y las mecánicas de los jefes son bastante interesantes.  [/i]

Ahora, mencionaré los puntos a favor del juego:
[list]
    [*] El apartado gráfico 2D tiene un arte muy hermoso llegando al punto que produce una sensación muy grata de inmersión.
    [*] La banda sonora ambienta excelente los escenarios y es coherente con cada zona, además de ser increíble.
    [*] Historia envolvente, como se mencionó en la sinopsis, a medida que se avanza, la historia va teniendo más sentido, ya que al inicio apareces en Ishlith Shrine pero no sabes el porqué, pero poco a poco todas esas preguntas se van respondiendo.
    [*] A pesar de ser un juego corto en duración, tiene muchas sidequest, paredes ilusorias y secretos.
    [*] Completamente kawaii.
[/list]

Ahora algunos puntos en contra:
[list]
    [*] La dificultad no es muy alta, es decir, cuando inicias el juego por primera notarás que la dificultad es alta (sin importar la que se haya seleccionado), pero poco a poco cuando le agarras buen manejo, el juego se vuelve bastante sencillo, tanto así que la dificultad HARD no es tan HARD...  Pero le doy un punto a favor al dev. del juego por colocar la dificultad "Casual" me mató de la risa esa referencia.
    [*] Como mencioné en los puntos a favor, la duración del juego es bastante corta... es posible terminarse el juego en 6min. o menos.
    [*] Presenta una pequeña cantidad de bugs, pero no es nada del otro mundo, son inofensivos.
[/list]

[b] Calificación: 9/10 [/b] ... Totalmente recomendable si quieres viajar por una gran historia y endulzarte con el apartado gráfico tan kawaii.

34439913.review:
Short game, well priced for the time. Great art and animation, very atmospheric music. Generic story, horrible gameplay.


As for the story, makes no sense, is not properly telegraphed to the player, no reason for it to be there really. The game is also sexist technically. Every character is female, not a single male human character. Why, probably because none of the developers were homosexual, so what pubescent wants to devote time to something that isn't a waifu candidate for them.


On the gameplay side.

Yet another two dimensional game where touching, some, enemies hurts the player. So in a game where the player can only attack with short range melee, and both the player and many enemies move quite fast, you also take full damage if you touch the enemy. Some enemies, most enemies. It's great, when half the difficulty is trying to hit a target that is running at you while you run towards it without simultaneously ever making direct contact with it.

Some other random obnoxious elements include, having to skip through a bosses dialogue every time you go to fight it. Having to fight a boss then complete another area all without saving. Having it so that dying flat resets the players progress back to the last checkpoint, this including boss fights, item pick ups and mini boss fights. Having a secret alternate entrance to a boss fight, the secret entrance having multiple possible ways to get into it all but one leading to instant death. This secret entrance, when you finally get into it after over ten minutes of trial and error; and replaying the map to get back to that point, literally leads the player to a boss they will fight if they just progress two more screens ahead; these screens not even having any real threats in them anyways. 

What a pointless, stupid waste of time that was. What was the actual point developer, you made a shortcut to a boss which skips the player over a checkpoint in the process; this shortcut requiring obscene effort to use even though it handicaps the player. Whoever designed that, incompetent. Utterly incompetent. Should not be a game developer.



In general, the best way to play this game is to equip the item that heals for each kill, equip the item that increases defense and invulnerability frames; and then just rush spam everything. That's it. Not only does it work, but it is more effective then actually trying to be methodical because so many obstacles spam the player and require stupid amounts of precision and luck to counter; it's better to just ram through them with invulnerability frames while healing from the kills.


Many enemies have very little telegraphs for their attacks, many enemies have projectiles with hyper tracking, many enemies have attacks with oversized hit-boxes. It is so overbearing, it's better to just spam through. This works, and is highly suggested, for beating the final boss as well because they are literally just all of the above in boss form.

Probably the best part is the bosses. They have either one attack, or two attacks. Fighting them is literally just trial and error pattern memorization mixed with human error. Better yet, almost all of them are generic humans. Better yet, the humans are so small; the players attacking visual effect is so large, and the bosses damage recieve splash effect is so large; while attacking the boss it's almost impossible to see it. So you can't even tell when it starts attacking, which often it has little telegraph for anyways, because all the visual effects block it. Bosses also have so much health, and the player attacks so fast that mashing the button is mandatory to fight bosses. Which again, constantly keeps the fighting particle effects active which constantly obscures the actual boss besides being spammy and annoying to uphold in general.



Wasn't fun, at all, because the options are; play recklessly and actually progress through shear brute force, or try to be methodical and actually fight but take triple more damage because the combat system is spammy so not spamming back just leads to you getting hit a whole lot.

33788637.review:
If you're interested in getting this game, I would suggest selling some cards on the Steam market and saving up the money in your wallet to buy this game. If you wish, however, you can spend the $2 to get this game.

I got Momodora III because I was very interested in getting Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight and I wanted to try out this game first. While I am still interested in getting Reverie Under the Moonlight and I DO recommend this game, it didn't feel like anything that spectacular at times.

[b]Combat:[/b] The combat is very basic and apart from spamming your melee attack or shooting a few ranged attacks, there's not much you can do in terms of combat.
[b]Characters:[/b] The characters weren't that memorable because they are introduced very quickly and are rather rushed. The story isn't a key part of this game, however, so that can pass.
[b]Soundtrack:[/b] While the soundtrack to this game isn't as amazing as Shovel Knight's or Undertale's, I enjoyed it. The music was, at times, very relaxing. My favorite track was the track to the final level in [spoiler]Hell. The music makes you feel so utterly depressed and pointless. It went extremely well with the snowy and barren landscape and it really asks the question- What is Hell really like? Is it the sensation of burning with other lost souls or is it a cold, lonely landscape that you can never escape?[/spoiler]
[b]Bosses:[/b] Most of them weren't really that interesting or engaging. The combat is very basic so it the bosses can all be defeated the same way.
[b]Artstyle:[/b] The artstyle is extremely cute and I really love it. The enemy and NPC designs are very cute and unique and I love it. This is probably the greatest part of the game. This is probably what compels most players.

Although I've been complaining a lot, my final complaint is about the final level. I put a spoiler notice when I talked about it before, and I'll do that again.

[spoiler]The level in Hell felt kind of ruined by all the random monsters and the boss encounter before the final boss, the Goddess of Death. I felt like the level would have gotten its point across a lot better if it had been without monsters and had been the player simply walking alone through a bare landscape. I personally think it would have been better played out if the player just walks by themself through a landscape with, perhaps, dead monsters or NPCs appearing on the ground in a few select spots. When they reach the final boss, they kill them and the game ends. But, then again, this is just me being picky.[/spoiler]

Okay, so... What did I enjoy about the game?
Well, I thought the atmospheres were very nice and, like I said before, I thought the soundtrack was very relaxing. The NPCs were, while rushed in their introductions, at least likeable. The game doesn't give you a defined purpose, which is nice. You can make any predictions or guesses, which I wish more games would do sometimes. You can also occasionally find secret items, which I wish there had been more focus on. The game feels like 25% of a Metroidvania style game. The artstyle is, as I said before, wonderful. You can tell the developer obviously put a lot of time into it and that's what I admire most about the game.


Overall...
Sure, I would recommend Momodora III. No, it's not the greatest game I've ever played, but it's worth playing and is a nice way to pass an hour or two when you're bored.
6.5/10

32819117.review:
本作はMomodoraシリーズの3作目だ。
アクション性が高く、アクション好きならお勧めできる作品だ。
ただボリュームはそこまで多くなく、難易度HARDで初回クリア時間は2時間程だ。

言語は英語だがそこまで難しくはない。文章量も多くないので自力で機械翻訳することも可能な範囲だろう。

ゲームはメトロイドヴァニア系のアクションだ。クリア以外にも隠された通路やアイテムを探したりと探索要素も少しばかりある。また、やり込み系の実績（スピードラン等）や周回要素も一応備えている。

内容
本作はシリーズ3作目に当たるが、過去作をプレイしておく必要は全くない。主人公は二人居るがそれぞれ、1作目と2作目の主人公なだけで、物語的なつながりは一切ない。本作から初めても大丈夫な作りになっている。

ゲームバランス
全体的にアクション難度は高めだが、事前にセーブポイントが用意されており、リトライで苦痛を感じた場面は殆ど無い。初見殺しはあるものの、理不尽な場所は殆ど感じられなかった。
またボスの攻撃パターンはそれほど多くなく、パターン化も容易な部類だ。

難易度
難易度は3つ用意されており、優しくすれば即死以外で死ぬことはほぼ無くなる。逆に難しくすれば、僅かな被弾しか許して貰えず緊張感のあるゲームになるだろう。アクション好きでも苦手な人や、普通に得意な人でも満足出来るはずだ。

総評
アクション性が高く、全体的なクオリティも高い。値段も安く、値段以上には遊べた印象だ。過去作であるMomodora1＆2はフリーゲームなので気になる人はそちらからプレイするといいだろう。雰囲気はつかめるはずだ。
アクションが好きなら買って損はないだろう。お勧めだ。

32023157.review:
Worse in basically every way than Momodora II unfortunately.... and that one is free! 

Momodora III was a dissapointment to say the least. Having played through the first two one after the other I was excited to see how 3 would improve on 2 considering the huge jump in quality from the first to the second but I feel like that didn't happen here. 

Pros: 
x Dora is cute! 

x The animations are very nice, definitely better than the previous two

x The colors are very vivid and areas a lot more varied than before

x Multiple bosses instead of just an endgame one

x Having bosses do dark souls-y large, damaging but telegraphed attacks is neat, though I feel like it doesn't work like it's supposed to

Cons: 
x Almost entire removal of all metroidvania elements. No more map or hidden health items, or a secret thing you have to get to get the good ending

x Around halfway or 3/4 through the game I got sick of it and decided to just rush through everything to progress...and it worked

x Holding S to shoot feels a lot more awkward than pressing up S, which made me rarely want to use projectiles (though perhaps this was on purpose?)

x I found that most bosses could easily be beaten by just standing next to them and spamming attack while tanking any damage...and this is on the normal difficulty

x It feels like I missed a lot but apparently I got 89% completion so I guess not! Though seeing the npcs again definitely would've made things less confusing 

x No more upgrades like double jump or dash, just items that I feel like didn't so much to mix things up when equipped

x Explosions kill you in one hit! This is a bit hard to get used to when they are normal attacks for some enemies

x Money bounces obnoxiously and falls through platforms, making it difficult to get all of it unless you waste an item slot on the money magnet

x The last boss felt pretty anticlimactic, I only figured they must be the last one while I was fighting them because they had multiple forms

x Reaaaaaaaally bad framerate drops for little reason. Going from 40 something to 8-19 instantly. Other two ran fine and my computer is decent, not sure what was going on there

4/10 just play Momodora 2

30892715.review:
Short but fun.

That pretty much sums up Momodora III.

The gameplay is good. You've got your basic sword attack, a ranged attack, as well as some equipable items with various effects (summon a ghost partner, upgrade your ranged attack, etc.).

There are various enemies, all with different attack patterns. There are several bosses, also with their own distinct attack patterns, however none of them were very difficult. As soon as you learn how they will act taking them down will be a breeze.

I'm not really sure what the plot was. You pretty much just have to find and defeat the bad guy (or girl). But for a game this short the story is not really that important.

My first run took me about an hour, while my second run ("speedrun" on the easiest difficulty = you are practically invurnerable) only took me 15 minutes.

So it's a [i]very[/i] short game. But for $2? It's long enough.

30880004.review:
Momodora III is a short action platformer. It is the third game in the Momodora series, but you do not have to play the other Momodora games first. I recommend you buy Momodora Reverie Under the Moonlight instead of this game if you haven't played it. Reverie under the Moonlight is the fourth game in the series, but it's a prequel and doesn't require you to have played the others. If you've already played Momo IV (or it doesn't interest you), then I recommend you play the first two Momodora games first. They're free; play them first! Now onto actually talking about Momodora III.

Momodora III's combat system is a lot like the system in Momodora II. The combat system mainly consists of melee attacks. Enemies also drop money which you can use to buy items to improves your character. The 'ceremonial fabric' item is incredibly overpowered, especially in hard mode, so don't use it because it will ruin the experience. The combat feels much better than in Momo II. The gameplay is fun, and the bosses are cool. It's a little easy at times, but I definitely still found it enjoyable. The game's graphics are very nice and colorful. The music is good too. My biggest complaint is the game's story. It features some NPCs I liked, but there's no real point where the story is explained to the player. Towards the beginning, you meet a girl named Mariel; she is the only way the story is explained in the game. You should know this so you don't spend 1/2 the game waiting for a proper exposition. The steam page does a better job at telling you the story than the actual game. There is an online manual (http://www.rdein.puyovs.net/manual.html). If you go there, you can read the story and about the characters; I recommend you read it before you play. Momodora III was pretty short and didn't feel like it had a real beginning, middle, or end. The game is linear (like Momo 1 but unlike 2 and 4). There are lots of secrets, and getting all the achievements is fun and not too hard. I recommend it if you've played 1 and 2 and enjoyed 2. Personally, It's worse than 2, but it's still fun and improves on a lot of things which weren't the greatest in 2. Momodora III is also extremely cheap!

一个叫做KoHo的小镇某天突然被怪异的景象笼罩着，小镇的人们派出了两名女祭司Momo和Dora去调查这个现象。


总的来说这是还不错的一款像素风ACT，从人物的动作设计上能看得出来做了很多细节进去，同样大致玩了一下前两代，从系统上变化不会特别大但是能明显看出是在逐步完善的，游戏流程很短，然而对我来说（尤其这一代）死在尖刺陷阱或是坑里都极大的延长了游戏时间2333  

说到平台跳跃类游戏的陷阱设计，在这里想提的一点建议是不要设计过多的即死陷阱在游戏的整个流程中，又或者是能够找到缩短从“死亡”到“复活/重开”这一个过程所需要的时间。在这个游戏中，需要不断地在“铃铛”处存档，然而复活也将会在这里复活。玩家从“没有意识到陷阱”到意识到“原来下去就死了”再到找出“如何安全的度过这个陷阱”的方法，这一系列的思考是需要时间的。可能限于技术层面，但是这里游戏所提供的存档方式确实会给人很大的挫败感，尤其是在这个流程不长的游戏中......   

A/S的案件会有经常按错的问题存在，后来实在是放弃了改用手柄玩了2333

游戏中有些隐藏的道具藏的位置很有意思，有细心和耐心的玩家可以仔细的去找一找。

相比这一代，更加推荐玩家们去玩该作者的下一代游戏——Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight  
不过因为自己还没玩通，所以暂时不会给那一款游戏写测评。
（顺便一提的是Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight有官方汉化，游戏更难2333 元素更丰富,流程也更长）

29428194.review:
Momodora III is a short platformer with elements from Castlevania that I have found to be really enjoyable. There are a total of 6 levels that should take 5 to 10 min. to complete, each have their own enemies and boss battles. You only have 2 attacks in the game, a standard slashing move and a charge attack. Both seem to do the same amount of damage so it ends up your strategy on how to take out enemies. 

Throughout the levels you will come across chests that will give you currency to buy items from a shop that can give you an edge in combat. You will get currency by defeating enemies (certain enemies drop more than others).  There are some secret areas as well as a level that will give you special items or a lot of currency. 

So if you want a Castlevania inspired game with good level design and no BS enemy placement that can take you around an hr. to beat I recommend this game. Its a pretty good game to speedrun as well!

Rating 8/10

29202617.review:
Momodora III is a platformer action game. I'm not too sure on the story, but again, I haven't played Momodora I or Momodora II. So maybe those games cover the pieces. You actually do meet Kaho from Momodora IV (and presumably, an earlier Momodora?) and help her with some shenanigans. There's a mini-story where you can save/kill a fellow Kahonese pilgrim. I usually try to save her but I'm not the best at beating the bee boss so of my three play-throughs I only saved her on my 37 minute run. 

Graphics are simplistic but nice. Enemies can be a pain. Especially the ones with bombs. I think bombs do damage every frame after they explode, so I got instagibbed by bombs a few times without realizing what was happening. What annoyed me the most is that when you attack, you're locked in place. Playing games in... the current year, in almost every game I've ever played I've been able to move and attack at the same time or at least to some degree. There's also no roll button which I tend to favor over jumps (because muh invulnerability frames). 

So Momodora III feels like it was designed to be a speedrun game. It has six bosses (if I recall correctly) and it can easily be finished within an hour. My first playthrough took me... 1 hour? The second 37 minutes and the last, an hour again. Just depends on which bosses ruin your day. A perfect run can likely be done within 20 minutes, including the time travel section. The characters have limited interaction, though there seems to be a bit of a sidequest if you want the "good" ending. I won't spoil the endings, but I will say that there's not much of a difference in terms on content and it's pretty easy to get both endings in a single play session. 

Overall, the game wasn't great but it wasn't bad either. I did genuinely get engaged in some of the boss fights even if I was annoyed that I had no roll button. The game's a little too easy though. You can obtain an item that doubles your damage shortly after the first boss and you can increase your basic attack's damage after the fourth boss. I don't feel like the enemy setups are terribly interesting and at some points seemed outright unfair. I'd say that this is a case of you get what you pay for. It's a $2 game (at the time of writing). It's worth it. It certainly makes the sequel seem far more valuable in comparison.

Por estar habituado a jogar retro games, me senti bem confortável do começo ao fim.

A jogabilidade é bem simples, com poucos comandos. Porém, a gameplay apresenta um certo nível de desafio. Basta compreender os padrões do jogo e não terá grandes dificuldades.

No caso dos players mais casuais, a campanha dura cerca de 1h30~2h. Para os mais "hardcores", o jogo possibilita um speed run interessante, sendo até parte dos achievements (apesar da possibilidade de conseguir de forma fácil).

Apesar da campanha curta, o verdadeiro pecado do game se encontra na questão dos diálogos x história, que deixam um pouco a desejar. Mas nada que faça o game perder sua credibilidade ou estragar a diversão.

Considerando o valor praticamente simbólico do game, não há desculpas para não dar 1 chance.

Mechanics:
Its pretty standart, A to jump, B to attack, Hold B to do a range attack, Move with the stick, thats how you play,
You can also equip items. It was mapped to X or Y, Tho i changed it to a shoulder button, so i could change them in battle,
easilly, Dont get me wrong, i only did this in the final boss, and even then, it was probably still kinda unnecesary, and pretty much nothing else, Im not saying its bad, Simple can be fun, and if it still is refreshing, it pushes the industry further, tho i will talk more on that later.


Pros:
-The combat against normal enemies is fun, and if you really have good control over your characters movement, you can pass them and just run, and take very few hits.
-You can pick from two characters: I mean, they dont change at all in gameplay, but its nice.
-Multiple difficulty settings: You have Casual, which, really? for seeing the story? there isnt much story, and its not like the game is that hard in Easy, that i would call normal, Start here, And hard, that i would call madness, you take TWICE the damage, and have 3/5 of your health in easy, The first boss kills you in 2 hits.
-New game+: When you get certain ending, you can play new game+, Is cool, you keep items from previous play, (Except for the keys) and have another item slot, that, ill say its pretty unnecessary.

-The bosses are GREAT, but...

Cons:

-Some of the achievements feel stupid, they arent necessarly bad, but feelm i wont talk much beacuse i dont have a food answer, just how i feel.

-A few enemy and trap placement kill you in one thing, and that is kinda dickish.

Overall i really liked the game, and even if it isnt that original, its great for 2 dollars, The two first Momodoras are free on the web, and im aiming for triying them, and im also aming for the sequel, Reverie Under The Moonlight, Probably going to use some christmas money on it and other titles i wanna play.

I've heard there was a different ending and I might replay this for that ending in the future! :) Great game overall. Looking forward to the next Momodora.

I liked this game quite a lot, for a short run down, this games combat is hard, mainly for the reason that enemies deal large amounts of damage, the story while short and almost nonexistant, was good, and the general atmosphere was godlike.

The long run down comes now

First the combat, as I said before, the enemies deal significant damage to you per hit, however, using some of the items you find in the game you can regain health, or, as I did, use low health to your advantage, and one thing to keep in mind about the combat, is that movement is necesarry.

In the end, I would say that this game is well worth 2$, its fun, and i would recommend getting whenever you can.

Gestion d'un minuscule inventaire qui est largement suffisant pour choisir entre les différents objets que l'on ramasse au cours du jeu, facilitant ENORMEMENT le jeu(ps: le succès du speed run étant grandement facilité).

-La vidéo du jeu vous inspire-t-elle ?

Is it worth the money? it's only 2 bucks, so...... sure, why not! the graphics and sound are very well crafted, many ranks up from the average indie game.

Is it worth the time? it's only 2 hours, but...... probably not. each stage is too easy, too short; any atmosphere one stage tries to build up is evaporated as you rush on to the next one. bosses might be difficult at first, but then become too easy when you figure out the correct playstyle. shops and items are a shallow system here, they seem more like a justification for the enemies dropping glowy bouncy bits of money.

what really annoyed me is the screen-shaking, every single time you attack an enemy. it's downright irritating and distracting. it makes it difficult to watch the enemy's animation cues for when they'll attack next (since there's no hitstun). and if they hit me? the screen shakes AND there's red flashing, so I lose track of my character, and hopefully I'm not jumping into a pit or some spikes during the recovery. this is the only thing I actively hated about the game, but I had to put up with it the entire time.

There's a barebones story, but since I don't remember any of it, it might be better off without the dialogue. I don't remember any of the bosses either now, actually. It has the standard structure of every 2D platformer ever made. it tries to have a little bit of everything, but it all averages out to a mediocre experience. Fun yet generic time-waster.

play Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight instead? not because it's newer and "more advanced", but because it focuses on its strengths to be a unique and memorable experience. That game will stick to your brain. Momodora 3 will slide right off.

25071510.review:
[h1]TLDR:[/h1] Momodora III is a basic platformer with captivating artwork/music, simplistic mechanics, and just enough variety best suited to keep you playing for a playthrough that will last no more than 2-3 hours in one sitting. 

[u] Controls/Mechanics [/u]
Upon start-up, the control scheme can be switched between controller and keyboard, but the game does not translate the keys to buttons when using a controller, so the controls required some testing in the first minute or so. The controls are simplistic to grasp at; you have your standard movement, slash button, charge for special attack, and menu buttons to equip accessories you find during your playthrough. 

The game allows you to choose two characters, which does not seem to affect the already bare-boned story that's in place. For anybody that's played a platformer, the controls, mechanics, and gameplay are self-intuitive; avoid obstacles/, take damage from foe on contact, slash foe X amount of times to kill, falling off = death, respawn at last checkpoint. The usual. At certain points throughout the game, you are required to battle a boss monster, which has a health bar quite larger than your normal NPCs. The bosses start simple with singular attack patterns and develop more as you progress during the game, never becoming overly complex, and easily readable after two-three tries. 

The platforming component was fairly simplistic; no overtly complicated tricks or puzzles, just regular platforming, trying to ensure that you don't die or else you'll respawn at your last checkpoint. Some enemy placements right in front of cliffs cause for a slightly frustrating time for the impatient player, but nothing that isn't easily overcomeable. Basic, average, but smooth/tight. Meets a standard.

[u]Immersion[/u]
The music, background, and artwork are eye-catching and immersive with the layering of images to create a more deep environment. The lasting power isn't much and the visuals are likely not to be remembered beyond the first few days after playing the game.

[u]Summary[/u]
Overall, I was able to play through the game twice in less than 2 hours. The game doesn't require much for a 100% completion, and there isn't much playability after the first playthrough except for completion purposes. That being said, the game was cheap on purchase, has solid mechanics and contained artwork/music that was captivating long enough to complete the game and enjoy the cohesion between the different components.

Momodora III is short.  It's one of the shortest games in my entire library; I certainly missed a number of things, but it was completed in around 35 minutes.  The price is fine, especially on sale, but I think the sequel is going to have more lasting appeal.

There's a couple cool features here (something about how the shopkeepers stock items- be it based on how quick you are, or randomly decided) and there's a general competence in the game, but Momodora III is probably not the kind of game that will stick with you over the years.  Small but detailed pixel art, simple combat and bosses, equippable items and quick platforming are all endearing; it's a stepping stone for the developer as much as it is for a player.  There's nothing wrong with that, but there's many other titles to choose from on steam- with more ambitious scope.

If you want a breezy afternoon game you can knock out in less than an hour (or speedrun), this won't disappoint you.  It just won't wow you, either.

On the whole, I do think this is a solid game; nothing remarkable, but enjoyable and pretty polished.

There is a huge complaint that persists throughout a lot of the game for me, though... all those shaking and flashing effects and just a lot of general visual clutter. They make the game a lot harder to play, it becomes incredibly easy to lose track of your character on the screen when it's constantly shaking or flashing about, it's really quite aggravating.

The combat on the whole though is solid, difficulty curve feels balanced aside from the items that can break anything, melee attack is fast and strong, ranged attack is versatile and safe, the variety of items allow you to build your own strategy. The platforming is a bit weak and minimal, would've liked to see a bit more in that department, Momodora II was pretty good in that regard, and it's way more vania than metroid in this game, very little exploration here period, unfortunately. 

The negatives and positives here balance out pretty well to an "okay" game that for the cheap price I'd say is worth it but don't expect anything spectacular. Hopefully I'll like Momodora IV better than this one, was a liiittle disappointed but not too disappointed.

Un minuscolo piattaforma 2D che risulta, purtroppo, un enorme potenziale sprecato.
Pixel art, musica, effetti sonori, fisica + combattimento, boss battles, item shop e inventario: c'è proprio di tutto ed è di ottima fattura.

Short and sweet action platformer.

A great game series, with the previous 2 games being free on rdein's itch.io.  

Momodora III is the third game in the series, and has everything you'd want in a platformer.   Great soundtrack, tight controls, and a lot of upgrades and great boss fights.  The game has beautiful pixel art, and the soundtrack is absolutely amazing.  

The only problem with the game is it's length, but since it's only $2 and you get 2 hours, you can't complain too much.  The game is short, so running through it multiple times isn't time consuming at all. 


Overall, I recommend Momodora III to anyone who likes action platformers.  The whole series is worth playing, especially since the first two games are entirely free and are equally as fun.  Check them out first and they'll give you a general rundown on if you'll like the game or not.

Oh, and small bonus to the game for achievement lovers. The game is pretty easy to 100%, I did a 100% run and a pacifist run and I got every achievement without much struggle.

23896835.review:
An excellent little platformer, was more than enough to scratch the Cave Story/platformer itch I've had for a while. Granted, don't go in expecting the breadth and depth of gameplay and challenge that something like Cave Story offers. This is a short but sweet platforming experience that will net you a handful of playthroughs if you follow the typical pattern of doing a blind playthrough, one masochistic hard run and then focusing on getting the reasonable achievements. 
The graphics are pleasant and nostalgic, the soundtrack is particularly fantastic and the gameplay is tight and satisfying. 

In terms of the story these are the games that appeal to me the most, ones that don't shove the entire plot into the players face from the get go and instead leave the player initially clueless, requiring them to explore, speak to NPC's that offer snippets of information in a natural way, read item descriptions, etc. Truthfully there is very little substance here storywise, which is expected from a game this short, but it leaves plenty of room for the player to draw their own conclusions and just generally muse on the characters and the state of the world, which helps fill the time while you're flying through the levels mercilessly slaughtering anything that isn't a friendly NPC with your leaf. 

My one caveat is while the boss fights are varied in both the designs and attack patterns, it's simply too easy to stand next to them and continuously wail on them until they die. Certainly this becomes more difficult on hard due to having less health or by not using certain items but it's still feasible. Granted some of the bosses move regularly and in a way that mitigates this but they could have all used an extra attack that heavily punishes standing still and continuously spamming. The addition of a flying boss that forced the player to fully utilize their ranged attack with small windows of opportunity for melee damage would have been beneficial in the sense of adding some diversity and increasing the value of certain items for at least one boss fight. Regardless, all the boss fights were reasonably enjoyable. 

All in all if you are a fan of platformers, you'll enjoy this and for the price there is really no excuse for not trying it. I'm certainly looking forward to seeing what the sequel has to offer.

23364159.review:
The Momodora series seems to make major leaps with each installment. The third game was the first to be sold commercially, and very much deserves it.

Graphically, it continues the progression from Momodora to Momodora 2, with more detailed backgrounds and larger enemies. The gameplay, too, follows on the previous title's advancements. This time you can choose between Momo and Dora, the protagonists of the first two entries, with Dora’s quest serving as the game’s hard mode. With either one, you collect items that allow you to use different powers against an array of monsters and bosses.

The level structure is something of a compromise between that of the first and second Momodora games. You have discrete levels, but can teleport back and forth between them at any save point. At the end of each, a boss awaits. Not only are these powerful enemies more frequent than in prior entries, they have much more interesting patterns and better hit detection. They're more fair, and much more fun.

While it lasts, this is a top-tier game, but it's extremely short. Though no platforming master, I was able to beat the easier scenario in under three hours. Still, that was under three hours of excellent action-platforming and some enjoyable light exploration, offered at a very reasonable price.

A simple, short game with tight controls, the gameplay gives the feel of a casual version of I Wanna be the Guy. Gameplay aside, the truly great thing about this game, however, is the incredible soundtrack, an interesting and mysterious story that is revealed in teasing snippets and left me guessing but fulfilled, and a gorgeous atmosphere that oozes cuteness, moe, and old-fashioned nostalgia, with a definite disturbing edge to it. I don't want to spoil anything, but there are some parts of the game that gave me chills, especially juxtaposed against the lighthearted artstyle.

23002922.review:
All of the Momodora games follow a similar pattern of "short but sweet" with some challenge here and there. There's a lot of careful and meaningful design put into combat and movement, with rdein taking a lot of lessons from how combat and movement worked in Momodora 2. The art direction is great, the soundtrack is incredibly pleasant and never "in-your-face," and there are lots of little secrets to discover as well as a big one. If you're into achievement collecting, it's very realistic to get all 8, which I kind of find nice sinec most games either have you grind out kills or time spent playing (this is terrible for MP games).

It took me 3.9 hours to play the game to 100% completion, according to Steam, so that might be a turn off even at the $4 pricetag. Overall it's a great journey and if Momo3 is your first, grab 1 and 2 (like many have said before me) before you consider buying 4 just to get the full experience. I'd honestly love a "boss rush" mode for Momo3, but the game can be completed so quickly I don't think it matters.

It's also a great toaster game if you're on a netbook or something and want something to play.

Some people are calling the Momodora games 'souls-like'

I picked them up because of those descriptions, however the only real similarities, are the lack of spoon-fed story, and some may argue that the difficulty is challenging with a bit of boss/enemy pattern memorisation required to 'git gud'. The narrative of the game is given to you through only a few lines of dialogue, and a few item descriptions (Sound familiar?). There's quite a bit going on, but this game isn't really one you go into for the story, and if you're not paying attention you'll flat out miss the story. Why? Becuase you're playing this for a short, sweet gameplay experience.

Gameplay is great. Huge step up from Momodora 2 (Which is available for free, go download it before you play this to see whats changed), except I'm not a big fan of the linear nature. Momodora 2 had a lot more exploration in it. A lot more.

Nonetheless, great game. Short game (less than 2 hours).

모모도라1과 비교해 전체적으로 떨어진 모습을 보여준다.
일단 왜 공격이 단풍잎과 차지 공격 밖에 없는가. 1에서는 단풍잎 말고 활이 있어서 원거리 공격이 가능했지만 3에선 원거리 공격을 하려면 차지를 해야 한다.
게다가 차지를 해서 공격을 해도 공격이 멀리 나가지도 않는다. 대강 캐릭터 발걸음으로 5걸음 앞 정도만 나간다.
두번째로 구르기가 없다. 1에선 구르기가 있어서 적의 공격을 피할 수 있었는데 여기선 공격을 피하려면 타이밍 맞춰서 점프로 피하는 수 밖에 없다.
세번쨰로 아이템 사용이 힘들다. 1에선 액티브/패시브 슬롯이 각각 3개가 있어서 원하는 장비를 장착해 게임을 쉽게 풀어나갈 수 있었다.
근데 3에선 아이템을 사용하기 위해선 쉬프트를 누른 후 직접 장착해야 하고 하나씩만 장착이 된다. 더욱이 원하는 아이템을 장착하기 위해선 일일히 뒤져 봐야 하고 도중에 공격 당하면 캔슬이 되버린다.
솔직히 1은 어렵긴 했지만 재미가 있었는데 이건 재미가 없다. 1에서 7시간 걸려서 겨우 엔딩을 봤건만 이 게임은 겨우 1시간만에 엔딩을 보고 말았다.
장점? 자동으로 회복되는 거 외에는 장점을 찾아볼 수가 없다.

Хороший, годный платформер. 
Что хорошего:
-Свободное перемешение по миру.
-Артефакты, по-разному влияющие на игру. Однако по-настоящему полезные штуки придётся ещё поискать.
-Небольшой элемент нелинейности. В виде двух концовок, дополнительных заданий и просто возможности добраться до цели разными путями. Да, нелинейность невелика, но она есть.
-Приятная графика. 
Что расстраивает:
-Мало. За 6 часов лично я прошел игру несколько раз разными персонажами, на разных сложностях, выбил все ачивки, собрал все артефакты и... спас Мэриэл. Такие дела. Хотелось бы moar.
-Боссы довольно простые. На высочайшей сложности проблемы создаёт только Poetelia. Остальные, включая финального и секретного боссов - убиваются как дети. 
В целом всё. Игра оставляет приятное впечатление. Если вы любитель платформеров - к употреблению рекомендуется. Для остальных есть казуальный режим, с огромным здоровьем и регенерацией.

Quick review to express my happiness and enthusiasm for this game. 

I have never played any other games in the series, but now that I have beaten this one, I will be playing the first two (legally free online) and buying the fourth at some point.

This game is short, take that for whatever it means to you, but I beat the game in less than two hours. "Charming" is the word I would use to sum this game up. Highly recommended.

22344724.review:
Like the two freeware gems that came before it, it's a little game with big personality, and a few rough edges that are more endearing than detrimental (think of a cute little terrier with a flopped ear).  Despite its simplicity and brevity, [i]Momodora III[/i] positively throngs with variety; the painterly vistas, fine chiptune soundtrack, and whimsical enemy roster are constantly shifting, and there are even a couple side-missions wedged in there -- one of which is a hidden boss, no less!  The story of this and the other games interlock, but the narrative is still fairytale-vague; there's enough detail for atmosphere and series branding, with the rest left up to your imagination.  That's fine with me, though.  I've always loved the "rustically cosmic" viewpoint of fairytale and myth, and if it's good enough for me, it's good enough for you!

The physics were okay in the previous games, but one thing I really love about [i]Momodora III[/i] is that Dora and Momo have a real sense of weight to go with their speed this time around.  They don't hop in unswerving Castlevanian trajectories or anything, but there's a fine heft to their little pixel bodies.  You feel like you are actually steering kawaii lumps of tireless, monster-bashing meat, not flicking around passionless digital ghosts that would feel perfectly satisfied in either state of inertia.  This game has nailed it where too many indie platformers falter!

[i]Momodora III[/i] is the very model of a low-cost neoretro platformer.  Though it can be completed in under 25 minutes if you rush, you shouldn't let that concern you, as the game's potential brevity completely belies the amount of fun that can be had from it.  

MOMODORA FOREVER!

21287015.review:
This is the first Steam game I've ever bought. The first digital only game I've ever bought as well. Why? Because there was something about those first two frustrating Momodora games that just kept me playing, no matter how many times I died or almost punched a hole through my monitor out of anger. "I will defeat you!"

And to my (pleasant) surprise, one of the major problems I had with the first two games was finally fixed... I had controller support! This series has always desperately needed that, because &$%@ keyboards, yo! 

To my (unpleasant) surprise, this game feels like a gigantic downgrade from the previous ones. The gameplay is fairly uninteresting, and while trying to play it safe and compromising between the linearity of the first game and the open Metroidvania style of the second, it just comes off as kinda bland. It's still okay, and more than worth the small asking price (on sale, that is), but a little disappointing for fans. Also, as many have already stated, it probably should have come bundled with the first two games, since they're already free. 

I recommend this in hopes that the next game in the series shakes it up a bit more (and it definitely looks like it will). The series deserves more attention, and I'll be giving it a download as soon as it's available.

21081621.review:
Like the previous Momodora games,  this is a challenging action platformer with physics and palettes reminiscent of Cave Story.
It feels good to play and has pretty nice level design. It's short, but some variable story events, challenge achievements and a New Game Plus mode add replayability.

An equipment system lets you customize your abilities and allows for some fun combinations.
There's a weird design choice that takes getting used to, but works out somehow: Your own attacks are drawn on top of everything else, so reckless rapid-fire attacking is prevented by the need to keep your screen clear.

Enemies aren't hard to dodge, but getting hit is really punishing. In hard mode, you die in 2 hits. You have to play carefully and strategically. The level design means you have to stay on your toes and can't cheese everything, even when you've unlocked some powerful item combos - with the exception of the 5x damage item, which serves as an easy mode for boss fights and can be avoided to preserve the challenge. 

Momodora 3 brings nothing spectacularly new, but it delivers a memorable good time for very cheap. If its genre is your kind of thing, just play it.

This is very cute and very charming game. Just by looking at the sprites you can tell that, though I will say that this game has some pretty cute sound effects. This game is extremely casual with a generous easy mode and a fair casual mode (I'm too lame for hard mode). It took me about an hour and a half to beat a casual run and then around 40ish minuted to do two speedruns (I thought you could get the speedrun achievement on NG+, but you can't). So if you're expecting a long journey, don't. This game is meant to be a short experience.

The gameplay isn't too complex, you jump, attack, and pick up a few items to mix up your journey. There's not a lot more than that. People have said it's Metoridvania, but it's not. There really any branching paths and only a few secrets. It's more of an action platformer than anything else.

The story is... not really there. Well, there is a story; "You're village is being attacked by monsters, lets try and fix that". You'll only learn that if you talk to an NPC. There's no explanatory cutscene or anything. There might be more backstory, world building, etc... in the previous game, but that's beyond me.

21000052.review:
Momodora III is the third game in the Momodora series, the rest of which are available to download for free with Momodora III being the first of the games on steam. Momodora reminds me a lot of Cave Story, and in a good way. Like Cave Story it uses pixel graphics to paint a beautiful and varied enviroment, has a great soundtrack, tight controls and people refer to it as a metroidvania for some bizarre reason. I never understood that line of reasoning: Metroid is a metroidvania, Castlevania: Symphony of The Night is a metroidvania, Bunny must die is a metroidvania, Cave Story is an Action Platformer with some light exploration elements and so is Momodora III. Having said that, like Cave Story it is a good Action Platformer with some light exploration elements, it's also fairly challening. Oh yes, by the end of the game I was certainly no stranger to the purple-haired lady on the Game Over screen. Fortunately the game offers three difficulty options: Casual, Easy and Hard. This coupled with shops, pickups and plenty of hidden treasure means that the player has all of the means possible to make the game as easy or hard for themselves as they want.

At first, the story in Momodora III seems mostly non-existant. You spawn in front a small shrine and you go on to steal a key to open a door to move on, there isn't even so much as a quick exposition for the player. There's a quick description of the backstory in the manual along the lines of: "Demons from hell are attacking your village, go do something about it." but it really doesn't give much. However, there's definitely a greater narrative in the works and there are a lot of things going on that the player is never shown unless they go through the effort to look for it. Maybe there's more in the previous games that would help the player understand what's going on, I honestly don't know.

The game has two playable characters: Momo and Dora. As far as I can tell there really isn't any difference between the two of them gameplay-wise. Okay so, playing as Dora gets you a shop where there normally wouldn't be one for Momo but the item sold can be gotten for free in the very next level, so why even bother?

Overall though, I don't have anything real bad to say about Momodora. Well... okay except for one thing: It's short. I mean Really short. The game can be completed in about 30 minutes and that's counting side quests. My first playthrough clocked in at a little over half an hour I believe (not counting time between deaths). Although, depending on your point of view this could be a good thing, The game is great for speedrunning and even if it's only 30 minutes it is definitely 30 quality minutes with nice graphics and a beautiful soundtrack.

If this sounds up your alley I can definitely recommend Momodora III.

What a delightful game. My friend suggested it to me, and having both beaten and enjoyed it, I can say that it was worth the price.

Momodora III is an action platformer, pure and simple. No puzzles, no fetch quests, no level system: just action and platforming. The player is given two different characters to choose from, along with a wide variety of upgrades and power-ups hidden throughout. The gameplay is simple, but effective.

It's the style of the game, however, that really makes Momodora worth playing. The simplistic 8-bit graphics are vibrant and well-animated, with lush, ethereal environments to explore. The music is fantastic, offering a collection of energetic synth melodies at times, while giving haunting chords others.

The story is scarcely given, but it does exist. It's the blending of it all that creats the experience, not any one facet. And clocking in at about 50 minutes, the game is short and sweet. Go buy it.

[b]tl;dr: A good action platform game, heavily influenced by cave story. It falls short on some aspects but, overall, it's really enjoyable and worth the price.[/b]

As many have already mentioned, this game looks heavily influenced by cave story, so if you enjoyed it, you might want to give this a try.

However, despite looking a lot like it, this game isn't as good as cave story. I loved this game, but I'll start with the cons.
The history is generic, the characters are not that unique, the 2 playable characters are exactly the same (same attacks, health, everything) and the game is really short (took me around 1 hour to clear it for the first time). Not to mention that most of the bosses only have 2 attacks and huge HP, so it gets boring. 

Now that I got that out of the way, let's get to why I do recommend this game. It may be a simple game, but the price is fair for what it has to offer, and it's really fun. There are 3 difficult levels: Casual, Easy and Hard (casual can be skipped, since the health regen it's absurd to the point that not even the last boss can outdamage it). Some events can be triggered with different actions, so you will most likely lose something on your first playtrough, giving it more replay value. The level design is not that impressive, but it's good and there's a couple of hidden passages that you may miss if you don't pay attention. For the completionists, it's also easy to get every achievement.

If you want to try Momodora I and II before playing this you can get it for free on this site: http://www.bombservice.com/games.html

As far as I know, rdein is a brazilian developer and momodora is one of his first games, which is really impressive considering the quality of this game, so I'll certainly be looking forward to his next games.

20235790.review:
Hard to give a thumbs up or down on this one - Momodora III is a well presented platform/action game, has a solid soundtrack and appears to offer a good challenge. But for all that, I find myself wondering if my time and money were well spent - its short length (less than 2 hours on my first playthrough, on Hard) isn't a negative by default, but Momodora's gameplay is soulless.

There's plenty of classic platformers around Momodora's length, but these encourage careful progress, skillful play and an understanding of stage layout and enemy behavior. In short, they're worth revisiting, and become more satisfying when one understands its intricacies. One quickly realizes that Momodora doesn't ask for anything so strenuous. Here, players can just make a mad dash for the next healing point (3 screens away, guaranteed), save, and do it again until the end. Stages and enemy placement and behavior are as simplistic as they come, and bosses attack slowly (usually with one heavily telegraphed attack). There is no difficulty curve - if you can get through the first five minutes, you'll make it to the end.

So Momodora will take less than two hours of your time, and less than five dollars out of your pocket. You'll see some pretty pixel graphics and have a soothing soundtrack (in ogg format) stashed in the game files, but the game you play will probably be forgotten by the time you head to the toilet. Is it worth it? The obvious wasted potential poisons the experience of the game itself - this could have been quite good, but when the credits came around I wondered if the developer was more interested in making the assets than the game. I recommend against it - I have enough games in my library that I certainly could have spent the time on better games. I imagine most people can say the same.

19775436.review:
A game about Momo, and Dora. Classic title. A short and sweet enemy-busting platformer set across multiple stages on your shrine-maiden quest to rid your land of annoying demons, chock full of so much adorable. Geez.

Everything controls fluidly and tightly, except for landings. On more than one occasion I would fall off a single-block ledge because there is a very slight ice-slidy stop, but it's nothing frustrating, Unlike the explosions. I hope whoever designed the bombthrowers and bomb-fish be put in time out for making them a one-hit kill. The bosses are rather simple, but still very snazzy, particularly the badass Bell Keeper.

The graphics and sound are, as you can imagine, designed to be cutesy and endearing, and indeed they are quite the squee material, but there is a sort of brutal, almost tragic honesty to bits of this game. The death screen is particularly egregious: a shriek, a flash of red, and a cut to black. Yikes. Several other aspects of the world, spoilers notwithstanding, had an impact that speaks a volume of the game's bittersweet style with barely any words.

As for length, I will say frankly that this game is very short. The mere three hours I have were all it took to complete every achievement(yes I was playing on easy, shut up). I was kind of begging for a "normal mode", as there was either easy, hard, or casual. Maybe some of the difficulties might be Japanified.

This is a great game, its style is something I would like to see more of(even in the game itself, incidentally). Quite worth the price, especially on sale. Perhaps the previous two titles could enter Steam in the future.

19714153.review:
[i] The key for this game was indirectly given to me by the developer for review purposes but it will not change the tone of my review [/i]

Momodora III is a 2D action platformer inspired by Cave Story and developed by rdein. As the name says this is the third Momodora game but the only one to be released on Steam while the previous two installments can be downloaded and played for free. In this game you play as Momo or Dora, two priestesses sent to investigate events surrounding the village of KoHo.

To start of, this is one of those games that can’t be judged by cost. Most people might think of this game as a below-average indie platformer but they are in for a surprise. Momodora III is one of the best hidden gem platformers I have played in recent years along with Cave Story.

One of biggest attractions of Momodora III is the simple pixelated graphics which I am biased towards so my opinion of the graphics will differ from the you, the reader. The environments of each stage are polished to the brim and each stage has its own unique atmosphere conveyed to you by its appearance and enemies. The character sprites look top notch for a 2D game and each enemy is graphically different from the other. Though there isn’t much dialogue in the game, the designs of the characters give them some life, especially their different attires.

Another important aspect of platforming games is the soundtrack, which Momodora III excels at. There aren’t words to describe the music other than it is simply beautiful. Each stage has its own music to go with it and all of them are jaw dropping to listen to. The music just gets you immersed into the game and flows well with the atmosphere it's trying to convey, further enveloping the player.  Soundtrack isn’t something that I pay much attention to but this game does it so well that I just had to include it in the review. 

The gameplay is quite basic for playformers of this day and age. You have to traverse through areas as your specific character, jumping and moving on platforms to make it to the end of the stage while avoiding obstacles. Each stage has its own specific set of enemies and their abilities as well as appearance correlate with set stage. In order to counter these enemies you have 2 types of attacks, normal and ranged making for a simple yet enjoyable combat system.

You also have item slots which you can customize depending on the stage or your play-style. Items can be bought or found in different stages. Like most platformers, after you reach the end of a stage you face a boss. The bosses have their own attack pattern and by memorizing these patterns they can easily be beaten. The bosses are very memorable because of their uniqueness.

This game also has three difficulty settings Casual, Easy and Hard so you can choose the one that you most prefer. On the easier difficulties you start with more hearts and items, on Hard it is vice-versa.

The only bad thing about this game is that it is really short and I am giving special emphasis on its length as it is possible to beat the entire game in 30 minute! However, with its cute graphics, fun gameplay and cost of $4 Momodora III deserves a recommendation from me.

모모도라 3는 1인 개발자의 플랫포머 게임인 모모도라 시리즈의 세번째 작품이다. 안타깝게도 1편과 2편은 스팀에 있지 않지만, 무료로 배포중인듯 하다. 엔딩은 멀티 엔딩이며, 성격 급한 나는 배드 엔딩을 보고 리뷰를 쓴다.(배드 엔딩이 어떻게 나오는지 아는 사람은 무슨 뜻인지 알 것이다...) 1회차 플레이타임은 본인 기준으로 2.5시간인데, 컨트롤 실력이 좋다면 1.5시간 내외로 보는것도 가능할듯. 플레이어블 캐릭터로 모모와 도라가 있는데 본인은 모모로 플레이했다.

게임은 흔하디 흔한 2D 플랫포머 게임에 그래픽은 도트 그래픽이다. 이 장르의 게임성은 이미 오래전에 완성되었고, 여기에 섣불리 시스템을 추가했다가는 지향성이 이도 저도 아니기 쉽다. 그렇기 때문에 색다른 시도에 성공한 브레이드나 페즈가 명작으로 불리는것이다.(물론 이 게임들은 그 외에도 훌륭한 점이 많지만, 넘어가자.)

모모도라 3는 이미 정립된 플랫포머 게임의 공식을 크게 벗어나지 않았으며, 이는 안정적인 게임성을 가진다는 뜻이다. 색다른건 전혀 없지만, 재미는 충분하다. 플랫포머 게임을 좋아한다면 충분히 몰입감 있게 할 수 있다.

스토리는.. 솔직히 몰라도 상관 없는듯 하다. 어려운 영어는 아니지만 해석이 귀찮다는 이유로 본인은 다 넘겼다. 위에서 언급했다시피 엔딩은 멀티 엔딩. 옆의 스포일러 상자는 멀티 엔딩의 조건이라는 강력한 스포일러이므로 주의 바란다. [spoiler]최종보스의 3차 형태(최종 형태)를 물리치면 최종보스가 훌쩍이고 있다. 이 때 말을 걸면 해피 엔딩, 죽이면 배드 엔딩.[/spoiler]

여기까지만 본다면 그아주 매력적인 게임은 아닌것 같지만, 이 게임이 가진 매력은 충분하다. 각 스테이지와 지역마다 달라지는 BGM은 그 퀄리티가 좋고, 게임 특유의 분위기와도 잘 어울려서 게임에 몰입되게 해주는 요소가 된다. 그래픽도 귀엽고 예뻐서 보기 좋다. 타다다다닷하고 키보드나 패드를 누르면서 하는 전투의 재미도 쏠쏠하다.(훌륭하다고는 안했다)

게임은 지극히 단순하다. 2단점프나 벽타기 같은 흔한 요소도 없고, 점프와 공격이 전부. 난이도를 다크소울(...)에 비교하는 사람도 있지만 하드코어한건 아니고, 플랫포머 게임을 한번도 제대로 해보지 못한 사람이 도전의식을 가지게 하고 많이 해 본 사람은 정말 쉽게 할만한 난이도이다. 볼륨이 짧고 파고들기 요소가 없지만, 저렴한 가격을 감안하면 그렇게까지 큰 단점은 아니다.

게임에서 가장 큰 단점이라하면 스크린샷이 이상하게 찍힌다는것. 그래픽이 독특하고 예뻤던지라 이 단점이 특히 크게 다가왔다.

종합적으로 꽤 괜찮은 플랫포머 게임. 플랫포머 게임에 관심은 있는데 어려워서 제대로 해본게 없는 (나같은) 유저들이나 플랫포머 게임 장르를 좋아하는 사람들에게 추천한다.

横スクロールアクションゲーム。
MomoとDoraの2人の少女が地獄の魔物に襲われた村を救うのが目的だ。
操作が攻撃とジャンプ、装備選択くらいのシンプルアクションで全6ステージ+隠し1ステージという構成になっており、ラスボス戦での行動の違いで2つのエンドに分かれる。難易度は3つあり、1番簡単な難易度は通常のライフの2倍で自動回復という仕様になっておりアクションが苦手なひとでも遊べるようになっている。ゲームに登場するアイテムも攻撃頻度の高い分身や低ライフで攻撃力が大幅に上がるといった強力なものがあるので、自分の実力に応じて調整するといい。
ダメージを受けて点滅しているときや分身を使っているときに見づらいときがあるが、全体的によく出来たアクションであり特にかわいいドットアニメーションが素晴らしい。低価格ゲームなのでこの手のドット絵が好きなら買っても損は無い。

19300551.review: A cute, short (~1.5 hours) pixel based platformer. The mechanics are simple and familiar, the boss fights entertaining in the classic platformer sense, and the music has that catchy simplicity of the digital soundtracks of yore. Several achievements add a bit more for you to do if you are unsatisfied with the short play time, but it's priced appropriately for the time you'll spend with it. Rather than really seeming short or sparse, it's just that there's very little filler in the game. Setups are rarely repeated, so you're running from new thing to new thing at a brisk clip. Thoroughly enjoyable.

19246290.review:
1인 개발자가 제작하는 2d 플래포머 시리즈. 스팀에는 1편 2편 거르고 3편이 바로 발매된 듯 하다.

게임을 처음 보면 동굴이야기 생각이 많이 날 듯 하다. 일단 2D 플래포머라는 근본적인 점이 똑같으니 말이다. 하지만 2D 플래포머라는 거 빼면 사실 비슷한 점은 그다지 없다. 스케일도 동굴이야기 쪽이 훨씬 크고.

어쨌든 무난한 2D 플래포머 게임이다. 난이도가 엄청무지 쉬운 게임이다. 난이도가 이지와 하드로 나뉘어져 있는데, 실제로는 이 게임의 하드가 다른 게임에서의 이지모드 쯤 된다. 그렇다면 이지모드가 얼마나 쉬울지는..... 각자 알아서 상상해보자. (대충 보스전에서 공격 버튼만 누르고 있어도 클리어가 가능한 난이도가 어떤 건지를 생각해보면 된다.)

난이도가 대단히 쉬우니 플래포머 게임 잘 못하는 사람도 엔딩 보는게 정말 쉽다. 여성 게이머들에게 추천해주고 싶은 게임.

사소하지만 굉장히 신경쓰이는 단점이 하나 있다. 바로 스크린샷이 제대로 찍히질 않는다는 것이다. 게임상의 불편함은 전혀 아니긴 한데, 이거때문에 블로그 리뷰는 물건너가 버렸다.

시리즈가 다 있었으면 하는 아쉬움이 당연히 들긴 한데, 스팀에 발매된 3편이 시스템적으로 불안정한 모습을 조금 보여주는 듯 하다. 아마 1편과 2편은 스팀으로 내기가 더욱 힘들어보일 것도 같다.

18880556.review:
Momodora 3 is an  Action-platformer with very cute visuals and fantastic controls, even with the keyboard. The game is very easy to pick up, even giving you a mode where you are invincible. The easy mode is tougher but still should give everyone a pleasant time. Hard mode is  20 steps up the difficulty ladder, making the game quite a challenge and testing your skills, your knowledge about the few enemies, the worlds and the various items you find or buy during your journey.

You can start the game as either Momo or Dora, 2 Priestesses on their way to stop evil and save their village. There sadly is not really all that much story in this game, same goes for lore. Every character in the game looks adorable and interesting and it's kind of a shame we don't get to know much about them.

I really enjoyed the level design, at no point did the game feel cheap and it harmonized perfectly with the combat and those really good controls. Besides the visuals thats what i really liked the most about the game, these controls were that damn good. There are also some secrets in the game, which are nice but nothing mandatory or special.

I found it sad that the game was as short as it was, it took me 1 hour finishing it, my other playthroughs took about <20 minutes or so. Even though it was really short, it was a really nice and fun game and for this price i can highly recommend it. It also makes me want to check out the previous entries in the series.

18527510.review:
I don't know if I recommend this game actually. but since I have to pick between yes and now, I guess I recomend it.

It looks and sounds amazing. I have nothing but compliments on those aspects. They put me right into the right mood and into the world they built.

The gameplay is where things get a little fuzzy. Platforming is good. All the right elements are there, the character size, the camera system, speed, platforms size and distance. Everything comes together nicely and jumping around is fun and challenging. 

The level design (or room design?) has its highs and lows. Sometimes you enter a room and a couple of steps ahead there's a spike pit. Seeing how fast the character move this is a very easy death right there. You just entered the room and is still pressing the dpad, you fall over simply because you didn't have time to process the room layout.

Minor nitpick: The first screen of the game tells you to press A to start (as in the xbox button). I am using one so that's nice. But after that is all arrow keys this, shift button that.

Combat is the main problem I have. Even some ingredients that made platforming great are getting in the way of a good combat system. The character speed and size on screen, combined with the range of melee attack, forces you to get uncomfortably close to the enemies at the same time making that very hard. A wrong touch at the dpad and you are taking contact damage or too far to do any damage. Add to that a ridiculous amount of screen shake, projectiles flying around, ghost companion, and the confusion is all set. I find myself squinting at the screen the whole time to find my character and it's just not enjoyable. 

Honestly I'm finding it hard to get over the combat aspect of the game. I keep closing the game and then opening again, because everything else is so engaging. I only played for 40 minutes, and I don't know if I'll keep playing.

So, reiterating: I'm not such a great fan of the game at the moment.  But it is very affordable! and others might be ok with the issues I am having. So, if you like what you see at the trailer I suggest giving it a shot.

18235979.review:
洞窟物語に影響を受けたとおぼしき横スクロールアクションゲーム（メトロイドヴァニアとかじゃなくて普通の面クリア型）。
操作方法はシンプルで、ジャンプと攻撃のみ。攻撃はタメると遠隔攻撃になる。あとは幾つか装備アイテムによって追加されるフィーチャーもありますが、クリア上必須ではない。
ほどよい難易度で一時間程度でサクッと遊べて、気持ちのいいドット絵と音楽を楽しめる、値段相応のキュートなゲームです。

18213022.review:
A  short, cute, fun action/platformer.  Momodora III won't take you more than 90 minutes tops to beat but it's a game with no fat or padding out and has decent replay value.  The most unique aspect of the gameplay is that you can find/buy various items that act as accessories and can have multiple ones active at the same time.  Even though the game is short, you can new game plus and carry over your accessories so use can whatever you unlocked the first time through right off the bat.

Graphics, sound, and controls are solid.  Save points are frequent enough that death isn't a huge setback.  There are three difficulties, with the easiest basically rendering you invincible.  Bosses look good and have some decent ideas but are mostly beaten by getting right up into them and whacking away rather than any particular strategy.  You can play as either Momo or Dora, with Dora being the easier of the two.

In short, a fun little pixel game that reminiscent of Cave Story in multiple ways with a decent bit of replayability.  Definitely worth the cheap asking price if you have any interest in the genre.

A short little action platformer that is trying very hard to be Cave Story, but doesn't quite hit the mark.  It has solid gameplay, cute pixel graphics, and a pretty wide variety of sub-items for various playstyles, though that's about it.  The game is extremely linear, level-based instead of open-world, with a pretty mild difficulty other than a few bosses, and can be completed in only 2-3 hours.  There's a few secrets that add a little replay value to the game, but there's not much that might compel a player to come back to this game afterwards.

Overall it's enjoyable for what it is, but there's not much there.  If you haven't played Cave Story, go play that instead.  If you have played Cave Story, just play it again.

I originally bought this as a direct download, but decided to install the steam key so I could write a brief review for it-
it's great.
Really good replay value, spectacular music, decent gameplay and fairly short length, but worth money.
Unfortunately it has nothing in the way of a plot, and the characters hanging around don't seem to have any reason to be there asides from something inane.
Basically if you liked knytt stories, Cave story or Iji, you'll probably enjoy this. If you're not into retro-platformers, particularly of the cutesy variety, you're gonna hate this.

There's still one area that bothers me... a long row of spikes that you look like you should be able to get over... somehow... hm.

There are some serious issues - there are some bombs which insta-kill you if you land just outside them, but not if you land in their center (???!WTFAAAA???) and the difficulty levels are sadly lacking a "normal" setting - only casual, easy and hard. And hard is more like stupid-hard, extreme-style. 
I guess it supports speedruns, which is important for some people, but they have no souls.
And the game-teaching can be a little obtuse at times - I got about halfway through before I realised you could equip items, or rather, how you did that.

Overall, 6/10, 1 point more if you enjoy this specific genre.

16854452.review:
Just came back from beating the game today, to offer support for the game. 

Momodora III is an easy, short platformer. You won't find any real challenge here, and it won't keep you busy for hours and hours (unless you replay it again and again). But for $3.99 or less when it's on sale, if you are like me and your first game was Mario Bros' on the NES, then you should find this a fun little trip into your earliest gaming memories.

It's a little work of love, it feels fairly well polished and has a great feel to it while playing it. The soundtrack is great, the person who did this, did an amazing job. 

I'd also like to mention you find numerous little items you can buy or find while playing, take each one for a test drive to see if you like the item, and what it does. They all offer neat little perks like reduced damage, healing when you kill enemies, and one changes your attack animation into something longer reaching and cooler looking.

Got a "New Game +" option at the end, and it warned me:  "Things will be a bit different this time". Hopefully a bit more challenging but not too much, I enjoyed the casual and fun gameplay alot. Highly recommend this game for anyone who was born in the 8-bit era like me. Just don't expect a challenge, there is none that I know of. Play it for fun and you won't go wrong.

Update:   Came to check and see if I had reviewed this game because my memory sucks and I couldn't remember. Yes, yes I have. 

The New Game+ offers no challenge over the original playthrough and if anything, having all the items and skills from the previous playthrough lets you absolutely slaughter it as if you were a God. Not saying that isn't fun because it totally is. Just, there's no challenge to be found in New Game+'s. 

Also, buy this game. Seriously, if you like 8-bit retro games and platforming, buy it. I actually got to talk to the developer a bit, he is a really friendly guy, who cares about his work. Support him so he makes more games like this.

　Momodoraは元々洞窟物語をリスペクトしたゲームで、1はほぼ洞窟物語。2，3とシリーズを追うに連れて独自色が強まってきている。

　アクションのみならずドット絵が好きなだけでも買う価値がある。
　プレイ時間7時間で既にやり込んでしまった感のあるボリュームの無さが難点か。

16618788.review:
Es un plataformas excelente, corto y sencillo pero satisfactorio.

Momodora III es la tercera entrega de la saga Momodora, que por cierto, las partes 1 y 2 son gratuitas

[spoiler]
http://rdein.itch.io/momodora-i > Momodora I

http://rdein.itch.io/momodora-ii > Momodora II
[/spoiler]

¿Se puede jugar este juego sin haber jugado alguno de sus predecesores? Sí
Es un juego esticamente maravilloso, muy semejante al estilo de Cave Story, el diseño de los personajes es muy bonito y también el sistema de inventario es muy curioso.

Dispones de 3 slot y vas consiguiendo objetos que te seran útiles cuando los lleves equipados (o no tendrán ningún efecto cuando los tengas equipados) y tu haces tus combinaciones; ¿Quieres daño? Quizá optes por mejorar tu ataque a distancia. ¿Quieres aguantar más golpes? Quizá te equipes con una botella de hada y el anillo protector etc, etc.

Los bosses son los tipicos que repiten un patron hasta la muerte y son bastante faciles de memorizar, pero aún así hay algunos que son bastante desafiantes (y a veces frustrantes la verdad). 
Sacar todos los logros no es dificil si consigues asimilar el control rapido, lo cual es el unico punto negativo que le veo, o al menos ami no me ha llegado a convencer.

El ataque es unilateral y tienes que permanecer quieto durante la animacion de este, si saltas de una gran altura tu personaje se queda "clavado" en el lugar donde caes durante unos segundos, hay momentos en los que parece que el suelo esta echo de cera y los enemigos, combinados con el enceramiento de los niveles, puede frustrarte durante unos minutos hasta que consigas matar al bicho o... vayas corriendo sin mirar atrás y recibir un poco de daño.

En resumen; es un juego de 8-Bit, plataformas bien logrado, con un control un poco tosco y unos logros que puedes tomarte como desafios personales y te llevaran, no sé, 4-5 horas conseguirlos todos, quizá algo más. Además tiene cromos de steam lo cual siempre es un punto a favor.

¿Recomiendo el juego? En rebajas vale 1'99€ pero encantado hubiera pagado el precio completo pues yo creo que merece esos 3'99€. Sí, lo recomiendo.

Sería un puntazo si se añadieran a Steam las partes I y II pero no va a ser pues el propio creador de la saga confeso que no se sentiria agusto vendiendo un producto que diseño para que fuese gratis.

La soundtrack es hermosa.

Solo, compradlo y disfrutad durante esas horas muertas.

16516850.review:
Short, cute, fun.
You play one of two characters, Momo or Dora.
Dora allows you to buy a ghost spirit, and that basically attacks for you earlier in the game, or at least earlier than Momo does. So, it sort of makes it easier. In this game, you gotta find out a lot of things by yourself. Such as finding some hidden items, finding some hidden areas, and knowing what works best and what item combinations fit your play style.
The game is short, to the point where someone beat it in less than 7 minutes. With that being said, its not surprise the stages are short. If you know what you're doing, you can easily beat the game in a short period of time. If it's your first time and you're a scrub (like me) it might take you a while.  You don't have to rush though. It's nice to take the time to explore, try to find items, kill enemies or just enjoy the soundtrack. (which is great, you can buy it on the composer's bandcamp.)
Since the stages aren't too long, the bosses must be difficult and take a while to beat, right?
Uhm, not exactly.
The bosses were quite easy for me on my first time playing, some not even hitting me. It just depends on your skill level, or if you know what the bosses do. Some people say they're hard, I say they're quite easy. The story isnt really explained all too well in the beginning, since the game is short there aren't many ways the game directly tells you what the story is, aside from the good ending of course. Some bosses have a very simple pattern, some have attacks that are easy to avoid. Some are harder than others. Heck, even some of the earlier bosses are more difficult than the later ones. 
The achievements and speedrun records will keep you busy. Try to get both endings, try to speed run. Heck, it even changes stuff up a bit and you can do a pacifist run. Aside from the exploring you can, trying to 100% it, or just trying out new item combinations that you didn't before, this game will keep you busy. You can waste so much time just trying to beat your own records, or even attempting to beat the speed run record.
I'll try not to spoil too much, so lets get ahead and finish this already somewhat long review. 
Momodora III is a fun, short, simple, cute, time-consuming, and amazing game. I would recommend it, even at like five dollars. Sadly, there's not much content if you just want to beat the game. I would definetly recommend getting Momodora III and at least beating it if you enjoy platformers, or if you want to get introduced to platformers. 
Its difficult to give this game a rating, since I love it so much. However, it's definetly one of my favorite games.

Momodora's world is deeply atmospheric, and I found myself taking my time as I progressed through each area, allowing myself to breathe in the mood and appreciate the music. Momodora III is a lovely little gem of a game, and it's clear that a lot of care went into making it. It's asking price is only $4, so give it a shot!

     I would advise playing this game on the hardest setting because it’s extraordinarily easy, which does not help its longevity. I beat the story 3 times in about 2 hours…
     
     All in all the game that IS there is good. I just wish there was more included in it for the asking price.
     
      Bottom line, do yourself a favor and get it when it’s cheap.
